doc.repnme: Financiando el saneamiento in situ para los pobres : una revisión y análisis comparativo de seis países
doc.abstracts: This study provides information on alternative approaches for the financing of household sanitation in situ, in six countries: Bangladesh, Ecuador, India, Mozambique, Senegal, and Vietnam. This information can help identify the approaches for best performance and the relevant factors to consider in designing a strategy for financing sanitation. The study systematically compares alternative financing approaches based on a series of common indicators, including the effectiveness in the use of public funds and in its identification. The authors chose to focus on those projects recognized as successes in obtaining a reasonable sample that was representative of best practice programs for sanitation. The study identified a number of useful examples and tentative lessons to help design the financing of sanitation in the country of a project. To replicate these experiences will require a better understanding of what promotes investment in a home country and what will be the constraints that limit such investment both in terms of financial and nonfinancial. The challenge of sanitation continues to grow at the same pace that the population grows, and in the same way in which the cost of not doing anything hampers the goals. The authors believe this study is a major contribution to address the challenge of how to pay for sanitation.
